Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Black Geographies and Industrial Toxicity in North Carolina

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Across the U.S., Black communities live in environments burdened by toxic wastes. This research project investigates the relationship between race and waste in industrialized societies, through a case study of aluminum production in North Carolina. The study examines how race and waste have allowed aluminum to become a vital and valuable material in the modern U.S. The investigators will analyze how racism has shaped work, social life and politics in an aluminum company town, drawing on the insights and supporting the efforts of impacted underprivileged residents. This detailed empirical and historical study of a small town in the American South will contribute theoretical understanding to a wide range of disciplines, including critical and feminist geopolitics, historical geography, environmental studies, American Studies, and critical race studies. Collaborative and arts-based methods will make research accessible and engage broader audiences in environmental justice education.

In scholarship on toxic exposure and hazardous environments, race is frequently taken for granted, included as one variable among many or an unintended by-product of larger structural issues. This research centralizes structural racism in 20th century capitalism, a period in which aluminum played a key role in establishing the U.S. as a global military and economic power. The case study focuses on Badin, North Carolina, one of the first aluminum smelters in the U.S and a segregated company town that is the site of a contemporary environmental justice struggle. Using a combination of archival and ethnographic methods to examine 100 years of Badin?s history (1915-2015), this research investigates and contributes to scholarship on waste, structural racism, and environmental justice politics. The investigators examine multiple wastes in Badin, from the chemical by-products of aluminum smelting and the unmarked toxic dumps, to the bodies of workers and environmental resources that are ?wasted? in order to make usable aluminum. They trace how different actors over the course of Badin?s history negotiated, defined and challenged what was considered valuable and what was marginalized as waste. The study explores how segregation and anti-Black racism have impacted the social life and the physical environment in Badin over time and what it means for affected communities to build political participation through suffering and illness caused by toxic exposure. Through participant-observation of Badin community negotiations to redress contamination, and drawing on interviews with key stakeholders in regional environmental justice politics, the study examines the potential for racial and environmental justice in the U.S. today.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Across the U.S., nuclear, chemical, industrial and other toxic wastes are predominantly and unjustly borne by communities of color struggling for environmental justice; yet race is often considered an unintended by-product of economic forces, and its relationship to waste appears incidental. My dissertation project, “Searching in aluminum’s shadows: Black geographies and industrial toxicity” explores how race and waste are central to the development of 20th century industrial capitalism through a focus on aluminum production. Aluminum is a ubiquitous material, whose physical characteristics and perceived benefits of mobility, lightness and speed have facilitated and defined the growth of modernity. The project is a case study of Badin, North Carolina, one of the first aluminum smelters in the U.S. associated with the Aluminum Company of America (Alcoa). Badin’s roughly 100 year arc, from its establishment in 1915 as a segregated company town to its present-day struggles with contamination, offer valuable insights into how the accumulation of racism and toxicity has allowed aluminum to become vital and valuable by externalizing environmental and social costs.

            Supported by this award, I conducted ethnographic and archival research on Badin beginning in September 2015, including participation observation at community meetings, oral history interviews with Badin residents, additional interviews with key stakeholders including lawyers and environmental advocates, and gathering materials such as scientific studies, legal/regulatory proceedings and newspaper accounts. The project was developed in collaboration with two partner organizations: the Concerned Citizens of the West Badin Community, a grassroots group of Black West Badin residents, devoted to addressing environmental contamination and racial exclusion; and the North Carolina Environmental Justice Network (NCEJN), a statewide advocacy network. As part of the research, I wrote and produced a play, “Race and Waste in an Aluminum Town,” which incorporates oral history excerpts, field notes, and archival materials. This play is a valuable tool to impact public knowledge and perception regarding race, as it highlights the experiences of Badin’s Black community that contributed significantly to this important aluminum smelting plant, and are now dealing with the hazardous by-products left behind by the company. The play was staged three times, with assistance from a director and professional actors: first, for the local community in April 2016 to encourage dialogue about how former Alcoa workers and their families have been impacted; second, in October 2016, at the NCEJN Annual Summit for communities across the state struggling with environmental racism; and third, in February 2017, as a stand-alone production through the University of North Carolina-Chapel Hill Swain Studio 6 Performance Series for the general public. The use of performance as a research method (to build community participation and investment in the project) and as a research output, is a valuable pedagogical and methodological innovation in making social science research publicly accessible and relevant. Through its multiple iterations, the play has incorporated insights from community dialogues and audience feedback to better tell the story of how environmental racism impacts industrial sites like Badin.

            My study of Badin suggests three general outcomes, as follows. 1) Race and waste have become intimately interwoven through industrial toxicity, manifest in workplaces, homes, and communities, but also in bodies and in the landscape itself. In this work, I use the feminist category of intimacy to better understand the race-waste interplay in terms of politics and ecology. 2) The invisibility of toxins requires communities to draw on scientific expertise to make political claims. I explore the opportunities and limits of occupational health (tied to jobs and the workplace) and environmental health (focused on everyday surroundings) for communities of color fighting for racial justice. 3) Having depended on economic production for its livelihood and existence, residents of Badin, as with other former industrial sites in the U.S., are struggling to come to terms with their past in the wake of economic decline. I consider what politics and possibilities exist for those who have become disposable to capitalism.
